ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You learn about neurons and computational vision. I will say that this is not all you will learn. The most important aspect of this class to me was seeing how Professor Zucker uses math to reflect the world around us. It's honestly very beautiful/awesome/intriguing etc. You will sample so many fields of math (differential geometry, spectral graph theory, multi variate calculus, etc.), but seeing how Professor Zucker applies these concepts into how neural processes is awesome.

Biological, mathematical, and computational perspectives for understanding human and computer vision. Consideration of increasingly more complex abstractions of the human visual system and the computational tools relevant for these abstractions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: too many topics were discussed, but none of them was discussed in great details. If there can be focus on one or two of the methods and on how to apply to solve real life problems, that will be great.

Strengths - you will learn a lot of math and see how that math applies to neuroscience. You will learn a lot about different machine learning models and they work. The professor is amazing and will likely spark some level of curiosity/fascination in you

Weaknesses - the course material is disorganized. However, it's totally up to you how much you want to dive in and really flesh out the content. Professor Zucker really intends to spark intrigue in you so you want to dive deeper and learn more beyond the course material.

The key balance in a course like this is pace. I simultaneously wish it covered more content in less detail, and less content in more detail. So, the main weakness of the course ended up being the finitude of time itself. I think the most rewarding aspect of the course was the level of effort that went into understanding each lecture, though this was at times also frustrating.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. You can audit the course and get access to the course material but you don't need to take it for credit.

I'm speaking with a bias here because his intro course / advance course were two of my favorite courses at Yale, but if you're interested in math and neuroscience (/ have a strong background in math and a familiar background in neuroscience), I would 100% recommend this course. The material is absolutely fascinating, and Professor Zucker teaches it in a way that will make you excited.

This class was my favorite CS elective so far. The material was fascinating, albeit presented in a "drinking from the firehose" fashion. Fortunately, you are only "responsible" for a trickle of this stream, so this is not as stressful as it may seem. If you think you would be interested in learning advanced mathematical, biological, and computational ideas and lectures on a (mostly new, to you) branch of math and its relevance to computational vision sound exciting, take this course. The hardest part of this course is perhaps not the level of the material, but being able to absorb the main points as elucidated by details without worrying too much about the details themselves. The workload was overall light: 5 enjoyable but, at times, tricky homeworks and a final project; additionally, Professor Zucker made the final 3 due dates flexible.
